problem_text:
Is a group G non-simple if it contains two non-trivial subgroups A and B such that AB ̸= G and ABg = BgA for any g ∈ G? This is true if G is finite (O. H. Kegel, Arch. Math., 12, no. 2 (1961), 90–93).

A. N. Fomin, V. P. Shunkov
answer: No; for example, for G being any simple linearly ordered group and A and B arbitrary proper convex subgroups of G (V. V. Bludov, Letter of February, 12, 1997).
